item.content:
This is part 3 of my California Grain Adventure.

For beauty, California is like the fresh, glowing, golden crescent moon; it is waxing steadily to a noble fullness of development.

  • Inez Haynes Irwin, The Californiacs (1919)

The California coast always looks so sunny and breathtaking, completely concealing the fact that most of the state is too dry to allow for a lot of life to thrive.

In part 1, I mentioned how California is a great exception to the rest of the US. Here’s yet another example: California is one of the few places where 4 of the 5 global climate zones (and 10 different climate subdivisions) occur in close proximity. Perhaps the only other place on the planet similar to California is central Chile, where this convergence is made even more extreme by the dramatic Andean topography.

Much of the state boasts a Mediterranean-style climate, which is rare outside of the Mediterranean Sea region. The one in California actually has 3 variations:

  1. cool summers and mild winters along the coast and the western slope of the Sierra Nevada;
  2. cool summers and mild winters, also along the coast, but with frequent summer fog;
  3. mild wet winters followed by hot dry summers with little or no rain for months, in the interior valley.

With all types, most of the rain falls in winter – not summer – which is unusual for most of the world, where the opposite happens.

Precipitation levels also vary from year to year. Droughts come and go; extreme, multi-year statewide droughts have occurred several times throughout the past century; regional droughts have also plagued different parts of the state over the years.

Furthermore, most of California’s rain and snow fall in the northern half of the state – in the Sierra Nevada Mountains, along the North Coast, and in the Cascade Range. However, most of the state’s population lives in the tremendously drier southern half.

Due to the variability in precipitation and the imbalance in population, California depends on a large network of reservoirs, dams, and aqueducts to store and transport surface water where and when people need it. According to a 2017 report from the Legislative Analyst’s Office, California has >20,000 miles of levees and channels, and over 1,500 dams and reservoirs. Make no mistake, California’s various flood control projects have been funded by the federal government.

Yup, a great deal about California does not, on its own preferred terms, add up.

This extreme reliance of California on federal money, so seemingly at odds with the emphasis on unfettered individualism that constitutes the local core belief, was a pattern set early on, and derived in part from the very individualism it would seem to belie.

  • Joan Didion, Where I Was From

In southern California, water travels a great distance to get to people’s faucets: ~25% of the water used in southern California comes from the Colorado River; another 30% from the northern Sierras via the State Water Project; and the remaining 45% comes from a mix of “local” supplies, including the City of Los Angeles' eastern Sierra deliveries as well as desalination, recycling, and groundwater.

Real-life California water wars (implicating everyone from local philanthropists right up to then-President Theodore Roosevelt) inspired the 1974 film noir Chinatown, which played down the extent of the corruption involved. Perhaps it’s no surprise that later dystopian movies like Blade Runner (1982) imagined a future Los Angeles of 2019 as a rain-soaked wasteland, after all the havoc that city officials wrought on the area’s ecosystem for personal profit.

The digital world is a lot of fun and undeniably innovative; search engines are ad vehicles and AI-powered voice assistants suck. Still, technology hasn’t been able to abstract away reality, and people seem to forget that it’s changes in the physical world that drive a lot of living standard improvements. Given how many people struggle in low-end jobs and how quickly tech expenditures are going up, claiming the internet is great smacks of “let them eat iPhones!”

Competition for water is only growing and intensifying throughout California, particularly in the Central Valley.

The Central Valley is very easy to ignore – not in any way as glamorous as Silicon Valley or Hollywood – but it’s as important to eaters (aka. all of us) as Silicon Valley is to smartphone users or Hollywood is to moviegoers.

Bordered on either side by mountains, the Central Valley stretches ~450 miles long from Redding to Bakersfield and ~50 miles wide on average, and occupies a land mass of 18,000 square miles (11.5 million acres) – roughly the size of Massachusetts and Vermont combined. This valley is predominantly used for agriculture; it occupies <1% of US farmland, but supplies ~25% of Americans' food and accounts for 20% of the nation’s groundwater demand.

This valley contains the world’s largest patch of Class 1 soil, the best there is. The ~25¬∞F temperature swing from day to night is an ideal growing range for plants. The sun shines nearly 300 days a year. The eastern half of the valley (and the western, to some extent) uses snowpack melt from the Sierra as its water source, i.e. it doesn’t have the same drought and flood problems as the Midwest. The winters are extremely mild with no snow, which offers a whole different growing season for plants that don’t adore summer heat.

The mild temperatures and winter rain support some of the highest biodiversity in the state. A few hundred different crops are grown in the valley, including those indigenous to South Asia, Southeast Asia and Mexico. Interestingly, some of that is canceled out by California’s Desert climates.

The expansive Central Valley is really two valleys: the Sacramento Valley to the north and the San Joaquin Valley to the south. The Steppe climate of the San Joaquin Valley is oppressively hot and dry like a desert, but averages enough moisture to support grasslands and other vegetation that commonly loathe the desert.

The Central Valley became widely known in the 1920s and 1930s, when farmers arrived from the eastern US, Oklahoma, Italy or Armenia and wrote home about the clean air, bountiful water and cheap land. This massive swath is now among the world’s most productive agricultural region – and has helped California transformed from an agricultural backwater to one of the crown jewels of the US food system. The valley now produces almost all of the almonds, pistachios, and walnuts consumed domestically; >=90% of the artichokes, broccolis, carrots, celeries, garlic, grapes, plums, and tangerines; >=75% of the apricots, cauliflowers, lemons, strawberries, and raspberries; and >=40% of the cabbages, lettuces, oranges, peaches, and peppers.

The Central Valley is patently John Steinbeck1 country. There are many fascinating places there like the Weedpatch Camp, the Bodie ghost town, the Japanese Internment Camp (aka. Manzanar War Relocation Center), Death Valley, Mount Whitney (the highest peak in the lower 48 states).

During the dry years, the people forgot about the rich years, and when the wet years returned, they lost all memory of the dry years. It was always that way.

  • John Steinbeck, East of Eden

Nothing much has changed in California and the Salinas Valley since 1952 when Steinbeck wrote East of Eden.

Farming and food production in the Central Valley are extremely vulnerable to droughts and floods. In a normal year, ~50% of the water used in the Central Valley comes from groundwater. During drought, when less water is available from rivers and canals, agriculture in the Central Valley typically depends on groundwater for over 2/3 of its water supplies.

As California enters exceptional drought, groundwater supplies throughout the Central Valley are being withdrawn faster than nature can replenish.

This is nothing new. Declines in groundwater levels have plagued the Central Valley for decades. Groundwater, according to one study, is effectively nonrenewable, because it can take centuries for aquifers to replenish once they are depleted, particularly in arid areas without significant rainfall.

Another study found that the depletion has worsened significantly since 2019, in a race to the bottom. Farmers need as much water as they can take out of the aquifers to farm the land in the hot and dry San Joaquin Valley.

When groundwater levels keep on dropping, land surface can begin to subside.

Indeed, the overdrafting of the aquifer is causing portions of the valley floor to sink. As diminishing water levels leave spaces underground in layers of gravel, sand and clay, the ground collapses and permanently reduces the aquifer’s water-bearing capacity. In parts of the valley, the land has been sinking about 1 ft a year, damaging canals and wells.

If the groundwater disappears, so too does the food production. That means food shortages and higher food prices. By 2040, the San Joaquin Valley is projected to lose over 535,000 acres of agricultural production. That’s >10% of the area farmed!

Meanwhile, towns in the Central Valley are beginning to run out of municipal water. Across the state, electric grids are also at risk if hydroelectric dams don’t get enough water to produce power. How are 10% of California’s car owners going to operate their Teslas?

Over the next two decades, California could lose ~10% of its water supplies. A growing number of scientists say the Golden State’s great “aridification” could permanently and profoundly change the state’s landscape and social fabric.

What would John Steinbeck have written about the ongoing drought in California?

What’s the flip side to the megadrought? Megaflood?

California’s climate, already chaotic under normal conditions, is only getting weirder and wilder. Even if California does get enough rain this year to end the drought, it doesn’t change the fact that the ongoing water crisis is worsening.

It amazes me even more that the scarcest economic resources – entrepreneurial ability and technical talent – are spent on automating a globally abundant resource (i.e. cheap labor) and creating new variants of digital cocaine that are arguably more addictive and more harmful than cigarettes, instead of solving real-world problems.

In California, water is now the most precious crop of all. Some farmers have realized that it makes better economic sense to sell unused water than to grow water-intensive crops like rice and almonds.

A huge transformation is happening up and down California’s Central Valley, as the agricultural labor supply shrinks and water becomes scarcer. Vast stretches of land are now fallow because there’s no water. New calculations are being made about what specific crops to grow, how much, and where. Millions of dollars are being spent on replenishing the aquifer that has been depleted for so long.

In the era of greater weather volatility, when water can be unreliable, adaptability is an asset.

Which is why landrace plant varieties like the Sonora Blanca wheat are important. Wheat production still requires water, but a lot less than growing rice, nuts or fruits.

ICYMI, Sonora is a heritage soft white winter wheat brought to the Americas by Spanish missionaries in the 1600s. It’s one of the oldest varieties cultivated in North America, predating Red Fife and Turkey Red. It’s also sometimes called Father Kino’s wheat, after Father Eusebio Francisco Kino who established Catholic missions throughout the Pimera Alta (present-day Sonora and southern Arizona) in the late 1600s.

The earliest known cultivation records document the grain’s existence in the early 1700s in the mountains of Sonora, a region in northern Mexico. That’s probably where the variety earned its name; to this day, Sonoran tortillas are more often made from soft wheat flour than maize like in the rest of Mexico.

By the 1800s, Sonora wheat was widely planted in California and other areas in the southwestern US; it was a predominant source of flour for the western population, until the rise of industrialization after World War I, when hybridized high-yield commodity wheat replaced it. By the 1980s, Sonora was commercially dead. Luckily – for those of us who care – Sonora has been revived in the southwest thanks to the local-grain movement that spread like wildfire across the US.

Sonora’s heritage earns it some clout by default. More importantly, the wheat has been adapting to the drought conditions in California for hundreds of years (shall we crown it “the OG California Wheat?"). This adaptability has made the landrace variety popular among California grain farmers. Drought-tolerance eliminates the need for expensive irrigation. Additionally, Sonora’s lower protein content requires less input from the farmer, and lower nitrogen requirement makes it perfectly suitable for organic farming (no need to worry about the nitrogen content of the soil).

I baked with Arizona-grown Sonora a while ago, and named it “desert dynamo.” I still think it’s aptly named and well deserved. Everyone was telling me it was impossible to bake a lofty bread out of soft wheat alone, so I made a 100% Sonora bread just to show them it can be done. The bread turned out so bloody marvelous it blew my expectations out of the water.

Thanks to generous friends at the California Wheat Commission, I got a chance to delve deeper into Sonora – with the San Joaquin Valley terroir (grown by Eck Farms, CA).

Sonora actually can be planted in either fall or spring. It’s an early spring variety that does equally well as a winter wheat in milder winter climates that don’t freeze hard.

In southern California, even if you plant Sonora in October as a winter wheat, the climate there doesn’t really allow for winter wheat to behave like a winter wheat, which ordinarily grows low and wide in late fall, goes dormant in winter, then emerges and branches out in spring to maturity.

Sonora has a relatively high protein content (~12.7%), but is typically characterized as a “soft” wheat – which befuddles me. The often-cited reason is that Sonora has inadequate gluten-forming proteins. I’ve never done individual testing of the glutenin and gliadin fractions in any wheat, nor am I interested in such, so don’t ask me. What I do know is that protein content of a flour tells you little about the flour’s strength or baking performance. Some amino acids that make up the protein are usually water-soluble and contribute little to the strength of the flour, so a high-protein flour can actually have weak gluten.

My last bake with Sonora proved to me that the flour is indeed capable of making a stretchable dough – far more stretchable than a dough made with other soft wheats like Frederick (7.5%-9% protein) or even some hard wheats like Warthog; and apparently stretchable enough that Sonorans developed large flour tortillas, burritos and chimichangas with it.

Sonoran-style flour tortillas (tortillas de harina estilo Sonora) are works of art; they are stretched paper thin and cooked on a hot griddle, producing small blisters that give them a smoky flavor. Check out Sonoratown’s glorious flour tortillas in downtown Los Angeles, if you haven’t. They are freshly made daily, with 5 ingredients: salt, water, lard, baking powder and soft Sonoran wheat flour produced in San Luis R√≠o Colorado, on the Mexico-US border. These $10 plates of Sonoran tacos are so spectacular that hundreds of Angelenos would rather spend their time lining up in front of Sonoratown than going to flashy dinners at the world-famous Tartine.

A side note: If you have ever spent some time in Arizona, you may have noticed that the most distinctive marker of Arizonan cuisine is Sonoran-style Mexican food, an approach to border cooking that differs from Tex-Mex, New Mexican, or Baja styles and is seldom found outside of Arizona. Unlike the rest of Mexico where maize is king, Sonora is a wheat-growing region where the flour tortilla gets special attention, although they still use corn tortillas for a variety of dishes. In California, you are asked if you want flour or corn tortillas with dinner. In the Sonoran-style restaurants of Arizona, it’s assumed that you want the flour version.

Sonora wheat berries are moderately hard, and lend themselves to milling.

Similar to Joaquin Oro, Sonora mills to a fine, soft wholegrain flour on the first run (on a countertop electric WonderMill set to Bread Flour).

Since Sonora is commercially classified as a “soft” wheat, a lot of bakers automatically pass it up in breadmaking and use it instead in scones, biscuits, pies, muffins, tortillas, cookies, and cakes.

In fact, Sonora has a hidden kick of strength ("desert dynamo") that makes it work for many purposes and many meals. You can feed your family all three meals relying on just Sonora: biscuits/scones/muffins/tortillas for breakfast, naans or breads for lunch/dinner, and cakes/cookies throughout the day.

If you are new to Sonora and other heritage wheat flours, start with a familiar recipe such as chocolate chip cookies.

I made two batches of chocolate chip cookies de masa madre (with sourdough) from unsifted Sonora flour. All of the flour is pre-fermented to boost the flavor and bioavailability.

Iteration #1

Formula:

Sonora Blanca flour, 100% extraction 100% 200g
malted barley flour2, 100% extraction 10% 20g
water 55% 110g
sourdough discard 20% 40g
beurre noisette (brown butter3), softened 25% 50g
extra virgin coconut oil, softened 25% 50g

salt 2% 4g

chocolate chips (Ghirardelli bittersweet) 90% 180g

Note: I didn’t use any eggs in these cookies, because eggs have been scarce on store shelves; whatever eggs I manage to track down, they are selling at record high prices. Government data showed US consumers were paying $4.25 on average for a dozen eggs as of last December, which was 138% more than the year before.

The process is super simple:

  1. Make the super masa madre: Mix together the whole wheat flour, malt, water, and sourdough into a stiff ball. Let it ferment in a warm place for 3-4 hours, or until doubled in volume. Keep an eye on it – you don’t want it to overripen and get sour.

  2. Break up the masa madre. Add the rest of the ingredients except the chocolate chips; mix until homogeneous.

  3. Stir in the chocolate chips; mix until evenly dispersed.

  4. Scoop onto a baking tray, spaced about 2” apart. (Chill the dough and the scoop first for 15-20 minutes, if you prefer thicker cookies.)

  5. Bake for 15 minutes at 300F, or until spread out and light brown.

Listen up!

Here are three tricks to the very best chocolate cookies:

  1. Use fresh wholegrain flour!
  2. Add 10% malted barley flour.
  3. Brown the butter to accentuate the maltiness of the flours. Do yourself a favor and get a block of high-quality butter: 83% from Wisconsin, Kerrygold, New Zealand butter, or Isigny Sainte-M√®re.

Voila!

A thin, crispy crust enrobes a soft center oozing with melty chocolate. Heavens.

Every bite gets a rich hit of chocolate in all its creamy, nutty, and caramelized glory.

Iteration #2

These cookies were gone within a few hours of emerging from the oven, so I had to make a 2nd freakin' batch.

I happened to have a few gorgeous beetroots (probably from California’s San Joaquin Valley, too), so I roasted the cubed beets on a charcoal-fired BBQ grill until perfectly caramelized. Then I pur√©ed the beets in a blender, and added some of the red gold into the cookie dough.

If you haven’t noticed, I omitted the brown butter and hot chocolate mix in this batch.

They turned out royally delicious. Actually, they reminded me of Mexican polvorones rojas.

Amid global and domestic supply chain turmoils (major supermarkets in the UK have started rationing produce), these cookies really make me wonder what would happen when California’s Central Valley falls apart… What would be the new normal? Time to build out my backyard vegetable garden?

This is part 3 of my California Grain Adventure. If you enjoyed it, why not check out my other breadstories and spread the word?

His nonfiction book, Travels With Charley, preceded other great American road trip novels by Jack Kerouac, Studs Terkel, etc. In 1962, John Steinbeck won the Nobel Prize for his body of work. The Nobel Committee wrote: “His sympathies always go out to the oppressed, the misfits, and the distressed; he likes to contrast the simple joy of life with the brutal and cynical craving for money. But in him we find the American temperament also expressed in his great feelings for the tilled soil, the wasteland, the mountains, and the ocean coast…” ↩︎

  2. I made my diastatic barley malt flour from unhulled malted barley, finely ground and unsifted. ↩︎

  4. Substitute with unrefined raw cane sugar. ↩︎

  5. Making a Mexican hot chocolate mix from scratch takes only a few minutes and can be adjusted to your personal taste. I used freshly ground toasted pecans & almonds, cocoa powder, cinnamon, cardamom, clove, tri-pepper powder (ancho, guajillo, and habanero), and coconut sugar. ↩︎

item.content:
This is part 2 of my California Grain Adventure. If you missed part 1, catch up here.

Stranger, let me warn you now. If ever you start for California with the intention of seeing anything of the State, do that before you enter San Francisco. If you must land in San Francisco first, jump into a taxi, pull down the curtains, drive through the city, breaking every speed law, to “Third and Townsend,” sit in the station until a train – some train, any train – pulls out, and go with it. If in crossing Market Street, you raise that taxi-curtain as much as an inch, believe me, stranger, it’s all off; you’re lost. You’ll never leave San Francisco. Myself, both times I have gone to California, I have vowed to see Yosemite, the big trees, the string of beautiful old missions which dot the state, some of the quaint, languid, semi-tropical towns of the south, some of the brisk, brilliant, bustling towns of the north. But I have never really done it because I saw San Francisco first.

  • Inez Haynes Irwin, The Californiacs (1919)

NYC boasts the best bagels in the world, which New Yorkers attribute to their magical tap water. San Francisco boasts the finest sourdough in the world, which San Franciscans attribute to their special air. The unseen native inhabitants in San Francisco’s damp, foggy micro-climate, they claim, create a special “microbial terroir” that can’t be replicated anywhere else.

And for a San Francisco sourdough to be truly “authentic,” the local history and mythology go, it has to be born in San Francisco with proper San Franciscan air, not in Oakland, Richmond, or San Jose. (BTW, everyone hates Oakland, except people who actually live there and pay half the rent of what people pay in San Francisco while still basically living in San Francisco.)

No one has convinced more people about the unique qualities of San Francisco sourdough than Boudin Bakery, which claims to have been selling the same loaf of bread made with The Original San Francisco Sourdough‚Ñ¢ for >170 years. According to the Boudin Bakery museum at the ultra-touristy Fisherman’s Wharf, the company’s mother dough follows an unbroken line back to the Gold Rush in 1849. Louise Boudin even saved the starter from a burning building during the 1906 earthquake. A museum docent will readily inform you the starter is so special and irreplaceable that the Boudin mothership sends its retail stores fresh starter every 23 days. Without it, they emphasize, the sourdough produced at those stores would stop tasting like San Francisco sourdough – and start tasting like Sacramento or San Diego sourdough, which is absolutely blasphemous.

Also, according to the museum, Boudin’s bread owes its special flavor to a particular strain of lactic acid bacteria that thrives only in San Francisco’s climate. Scientists identified it here in 1970, so they named it Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis.

It’s a great, great story. Too bad it’s not quite true.

Scientists did identify Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis in San Francisco. But recent studies have found it in 90% of the world’s sourdough, too. So from a biological standpoint, San Francisco sourdough is not all that distinctive – or unique to San Francisco.

If you take your precious local sourdough starter and bake with it in Los Angeles, I bet the resulting bread will taste very similar to what you make in San Francisco. Blasphemy! But likely…true. Even breads made without Lactobacillus sanfranciscensis can taste pretty darn good.

So much for the “microbial terroir” myth. Even bakers who have been in a position to benefit from the reputation of local sourdough don’t embrace the cachet. Call a dog a dog – it’s pure marketing. It sells the city, turning sourdough into another tourist attraction that San Francisco is famous for, besides the bridge and the bay.

There are 3 bread institutions in the San Francisco Bay Area: Acme, Semifreddi’s, and Tartine.

Acme is often credited as an OG pioneer of the San Francisco Bay Area’s “Bread Revolution,” which in turn galvanized the modern “artisan bread” movement across America; to this day, Acme’s bread remains a “benchmark” for commercial handmade bread. It was a stalwart of the 1980s artisan baking scene, along with Semifreddi’s.

Newer upstarts like Tartine and Josey Baker Bread have brought on some serious competition, and challenged the status quo of what San Francisco bread is supposed to taste like and, along the way, the status quo of home baking.

In 2006, the NY Times food columnist Mark Bittman wrote about a NYC baker named Jim Lahey, the man behind Sullivan Street Bakery who had developed a no-knead bread recipe that consisted of only 4 steps and required just 4 ingredients – flour, water, salt, and yeast. While not the OG recipe of its kind, the “no-knead” method spread like wildfire. It revolutionized the food world; its simplicity miraculously democratized breadmaking for the home baker. Lahey became a semi-god figure – the Prometheus who gifted the art of breadmaking to the masses. He released a cookbook in 2009, titled My Bread: The Revolutionary No-Work, No-Knead Method.

A few years earlier, a transplanted New Yorker named Elizabeth Pruitt and her husband Chad Robertson moved their tiny baking operation from Point Reyes, California south to an unassuming corner of Guerrero Street, at the edge of the Mission District in San Francisco. They named it Tartine, and churned out artisan breads, viennoiseries and sandwiches. The bakery garnered praise from Alice Waters and Martha Stewart, and made the cake for a “bohemian bourgeois”-themed birthday party attended by Nancy Pelosi and Hillary Clinton. Mark Bittman described their shop as one of the best French-style bakeries in the country, and particularly raved about Tartine’s sandwiches, which were made on “Mr. Robertson’s exceptional bread, notable because it’s a slow-fermented yeast bread in very French style that is a welcome change from the ubiquitous sourdough.”

San Franciscans started lining up outside the shop to get a taste of what Prueitt and Robertson were baking; the queues outside Tartine became a local landmark and a symbol of a changing city. (Lines beget lines; the success of Tartine’s OG location is arguably one of the reasons that San Francisco gained a reputation as a place where people would wait in line for any sort of “cult” food item.) Tartine’s bread started to become a Veblen good, just as Prueitt and Robertson started to become food-world celebrities. In 2010, the influential Tartine Bread was published; Robertson revealed to the world his recipe for French-style sourdough, which called for folding, shaping, scoring, and a grasp of wild yeast. The change from Lahey’s no-knead bread to Robertson’s sourdough was remarkable; home baking was about to become more technical and more precise.

The complete recipe for Basic Country Bread, the edible hero of Tartine Bread, runs 38 pages, including photographs. It was instantly celebrated as a “masterpiece” in media, along the lines of a Martin Scorsese tracking shot or a Marcel Proust sentence.

Robertson wrote about bread in a detailed but flexible way: The prose is lean and direct; the instructions don’t just tell you what to do but explain why, what to look for, and how to make corrections, encouraging you to see his laborious artisan craft as adaptable and welcoming of interpretation. Robertson was also a laid-back surfer who radiated a particular kind of Gen X bohemianism, which inadvertently imbued breadmaking with a sort of new masculine sheen.

Seemingly, Robertson gave away the store. The bread he teaches you to make is essentially the same bread that has turned him into one of the most influential bakers in the world; it’s what causes otherwise rational adults to mob the line at Tartine Bakery. The fact is, Tartine multiplied its influence by opening up about the way they do things.

Tartine Bread could have merely been aspirational, but it’s just too actionable. The recipes work, and they inspire. All of a sudden, many of Tartine’s fans took up artisan baking at home – a majority of whom happened to be guys in tech.

For tech geeks in the San Francisco Bay Area, Tartine Bread had it all:

  • a recipe that encouraged iteration and a grasp of the scientific nature of wild fermentation;
  • a craft that was not frivolous or quintessentially feminine like making cupcakes; and
  • a cool leader that inspires emulation.

Technologists stormed sourdough with a host of tools and techniques that built on Robertson’s artisan approach. Ken Forkish, who had quit his job at IBM to become a baker, wrote Flour Water Salt Yeast and won a James Beard Award in 2013. Nathan Myhrvold, the former CTO of Microsoft and current CEO of patent and investment firm Intellectual Ventures, released a 5-volume cookbook called Modernist Bread in 2017. It also won a James Beard. High-efficiency tools like $150 Br√∏d & Taylor Folding Bread Proofer that offers “precision control” over temperature and humidity, or the $300 Fourneau bread oven, which “traps steam and radiates powerful heat” and “helps you achieve oven spring”, came on the market.

Overnight, Silicon Valley venture capitalists started tweeting about their fine sourdough starters; UX designers started buying $600 bannetons and taking extensive notes about each bake in apps like Evernote, Google Keep, Notion and Bear; and tender #crumbshots popped up all over breadstagram. Everyone in Silicon Valley is Very Publicly Into Sourdough All of a Sudden. People couldn’t delight more in the miracles of this alchemy than if it were neolithic times and bread was just invented yesterday. Breadmaking has become the latest form of romantic consumerism.

The Perfect Loaf, a sourdough bread blog launched in 2013 by Maurizio Leo, a software engineer by trade, is frequently cited as an entry point to baking for men in tech, as his approach speaks to technically-oriented individuals and, as his blog name implies, is pursuant of mastery.

Breadmaking is now seen as a sort of an “algorithm”; it’s expected to produce a certain result and if that result isn’t always what you expect, you step back and diagnose the steps along the way. Working on bread recipes has become a new form of “debugging.” That iterative procedure for optimization appeals to the engineering mind, not to mention the precision part. Breadmaking also offers various degrees of freedom – it could be implemented in lots of different possible ways.

It’s a liberating escape, particularly when you work in tech for a living and can’t turn that technical side of your brain off and your work becomes so embedded in your life that it consumes you.

Like religion, romanticism also has its liminal rituals, which decouple the subjective feelings of pleasure and freedom from material goods and mass-marketed symbols, and disrupt the daily tedium and hierarchies, transporting us, through the consumption of goods and services labeled romantic, into a fantastic world in which ordinary annoyances, our own limitations and, with a little luck, even our most objectionable caprices, are temporarily interrupted. Maybe baking is an opportunity for these technologists to rehabilitate their humanity, when they are not busy creating apps that make money off everyone’s “addiction”?

Sourdough, a 2017 novel by Robin Sloan, pokes fun at the obnoxious foodie culture of Silicon Valley while also ribbing the folks who are so eager to innovate it – the tech guys who obsess over an ancient idea, commit to disrupting it, then get bored and move on.

The reason that Chad Robertson became a god among tech-oriented breadmaking hobbyists is perhaps more shallow than one might think: Robertson and Tartine are instrumental to this whole trend because he was in San Francisco just as this mid-2000s tech wave was taking off. Right place, right time. Right guy, right craft.

When Robertson spoke about the intersection of tech and bread at a Wired conference in 2015, he said as much, noting that the reason he and Prueitt even moved their bakery to San Francisco in the first place was because the burst of the dotcom bubble in the early 2000s finally made it affordable for them to do so: The median rent for a two-bedroom apartment had fallen from $3,000 a month to just under $2,000. Development had slowed, evictions and unemployment had spiked, and commercial vacancies had risen. In the Mission District, a historically working-class and Latino neighborhood, artists' spaces battled with real-estate developers.

Tartine had thrived during an economic downturn. Now it’s operating in one of the most expensive cities in the world, where a 21-year-old earning low six-figures is considered a peasant.

Tartine has undergone rapid expansion since Chad Robertson personally manned the ovens at the OG store on Guerrero Street, shuttling out a limited number of loaves every evening.

In 2014, the Oakland-born and San Francisco-raised Blue Bottle, the most dominant company riding the “third wave” coffee trend, had just raised $45 million dollars in venture capital for its own expansion, and needed a bakery partner to provide food in its coffee shops. Tartine soon announced a merger with the company; the news turned heads in the northern California food world and beyond. Anticipating a personal windfall, Prueitt and Robertson moved into a luxurious circa 1960 house in the Castro district in 2015. Eater SF did a photo shoot of their newly remodeled home kitchen, showing off their specialized kitchenware and verdant backyard.

By February 2016 when the Eater piece went live, the Blue Bottle acquisition had fallen apart. The couple put the Castro house up for sale and quietly moved out in early 2018. Still, Tartine Manufactory, a restaurant and bar concept conceived in their sleek, airy home kitchen, opened in the summer of 2016. Eater SF lauded the 5,000-sqft space as “an artisanal utopia in the Mission”; every detail was designed to represent “a new type of luxury.” Meanwhile, Tartine launched its own coffee brand, Coffee Manufactory, in partnership with a former Starbucks executive who is now the Chief Operations Officer of Tartine.

One of Tartine’s partners and investors is a real-estate private-equity firm called CIM Group, one of the largest property owners in Los Angeles and a prominent commercial landlord in Oakland, managing about $30 billion dollars in assets.

Tartine’s Coffee Manufactory planned to move into Jack London Square, a 434,000-sqft waterfront property in Oakland acquired by CIM in 2016 as part of a $131 million deal for long-term development. CIM billed the Coffee Manufactory as an anchor tenant – a business that could attract customers and other businesses, increasing the overall value and cachet of the area. The developer was curating the neighborhood with buildings and tenants.

Tartine was a particularly appealing anchor tenant. The food was great, and most of it could be made off-site, requiring a fairly modest square footage for retail sites. And Tartine had a history: the flagship location, with its artistic staff and communal ambiance, radiated the sort of authenticity that a real-estate developer could only dream of cultivating. Year on year, Tartine‚Äôs brand had become cooler, airier, and more transportable.

  • Anna Wiener, “When Baking and Real Estate Collide”, The New Yorker

Images of Tartine’s pastries and its OG Guerrero Street bakery started to pop up in Apple commercials and product demos. Sweetgreen, the East Coast fast-casual salad chain that was now proliferating along the West Coast, started to offer “The Tartine Bowl”, plucked from Prueitt’s recently published book Tartine All Day.

Tartine’s brand became another recognizable symbol of gentrification; the opening of a Tartine seemed to hint that a neighborhood was on the cusp of it. The process of bringing intense, aggressive real-estate development to upper-middle-class neighborhoods, to cater to an even more affluent stratum, is gentrification on steroids.

In January 2019, Tartine opened the Manufactory Food Hall in San Francisco International Airport.

That spring, Tartine opened a splashy new 40,000-sqft Tartine Manufactory – three times the size of its first Manufactory in San Francisco – in the Row, a huge, newly developed compound in Downtown Los Angeles (DTLA). Food & Wine published a feature on Robertson and Prueitt, with the headline “With L.A. Opening, Tartine Positions Itself for World Domination.” F*ck yeah, Silicon Valley-style.

CIM invested in Tartine’s 5 new locations in Los Angeles (Silver Lake, West Hollywood, Santa Monica, West Adams, and Pasadena). For any Angeleno who’s ever wondered just how all these Tartines landed in the Southland in the first place, here’s an answer.

In July 2019, Tartine opened its 3rd San Francisco location, in a CIM-affiliated property in the Inner Sunset neighborhood.

In September 2019, Tartine opened its 5th Bay Area location in Berkeley. The caf√© is tucked into a sunroom at Berkeley’s Graduate Hotel (fka. the Hotel Durant), a chain hotel owned by Adventurous Journeys Capital, a self-described “vertically integrated real estate investment manager focused on developing and operating transformative real estate assets in spaces often overlooked or undervalued by traditional investment firms.” Tartine’s new presence at the hotel came as part of a ~$50 million transformation from the Hotel Durant to the Graduate Hotel.

Customers who walk into any of Tartine’s locations may never feel or realize they are entering part of a real-estate empire.

How much of Tartine is owned by CIM and how deeply these two companies are intertwined has never been publicly disclosed. The daughter of a co-founder of CIM is now Tartine’s VP of Brand.

Today, Tartine operates 3 locations in the San Francisco Bay Area, 5 in Los Angeles, and 6 licensed locations in Seoul (one of which is located at Kinfolk Dosan, a cultural space created by Kinfolk, an aspirational lifestyle magazine). How can a craft bakery still be artisanal if it has 6 overseas branches?

Tartine’s workers in San Francisco watched investment flow into the new locations and increasingly felt neglected. They suspected they were the actual engine that propelled Tartine into an empire, but now they couldn’t even get a $1/hour raise. There was a lot of confusion about the company’s investors – who were they, and how much power did they wield? Money to pay invoices wasn’t there.

Tartine was expanding, but the OG Mission location was falling apart. In November 2019, the San Francisco Department of Public Health briefly shut down Tartine’s Guerrero Street location, after inspectors say that its operators failed to deal with a persistent rodent infestation in the space.

Workers noticed cultural changes. Shift wine was eliminated, and management introduced a monthly music playlist. Some were dissatisfied with wages, raises, and scheduling. Employees wanted certain benefits, such as paid time off separate from state-mandated sick leave, and raises larger than the annual increases mandated by the city. All this looked feasible to them, given the company‚Äôs expansion. When they brought these requests to Tartine‚Äôs newly created human-resources department, they were confused to find that it was run out of offices leased from CIM affiliates, in Los Angeles.

  • Anna Wiener, “When Baking and Real Estate Collide”, The New Yorker

As Tartine expanded rapidly in the last 6-7 years, operational difficulties grew with it. Money was allocated to ventures that didn’t pan out. The whole enterprise seemed stretched thin. There seemed to be a fundamental disconnect between perception and reality. New investment was focused on new ventures, but Tartine’s expansion relied on the strength of its brand.

Bar Tartine closed in 2016 and had never turned a profit (since it opened in 2005 just a couple of blocks away from the OG Tartine Bakery). The planned Coffee Manufactory retail space in Jack London Square never opened.

In December 2019, Tartine’s massive DTLA Manufactory shuttered – 11 months after it opened. It was a shocking closure. The store laid off its remaining workers 10 days before Christmas.

Tartine‚Äôs market, retail baking and takeaway spaces, and multiple restaurants all closed this week after just 11 months of business and a build-out rumored to have run into the tens of millions of dollars. All of the Row is struggling to find sustained weeknight retail traffic right now, but the loss of anchor tenant Tartine has hit the development‚Äôs brand particularly hard. There simply were not enough $72 mug buyers around to keep the place afloat, and that seems to say something about Tartine‚Äôs visibility and draw, and about the Row overall ‚Äî not to mention the cost of goods inside. …

Simply put: Tartine didn‚Äôt find a good way to consistently speak to Angelenos, and in a city where driving four miles to have dinner can mean sitting in your car for an hour, answering the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù of the place not only proved tricky, it likely proved its undoing. … More than anything, it struggled to define its place at the Row, in Downtown, in a city brimming with home bakers and panaderias and other local bread legends like Friends & Family, Clark Street, and Bub & Grandma‚Äôs.

  • Eater LA, “Tartine’s Big DTLA Manufactory Closed After Just One Year. What Happened?”

Tartine took on a new investor, Monogram Capital Partners, another private-equity firm “focused exclusively on consumer and retail companies.”

Meanwhile, Chad Robertson started to show up in sponsored content for Blundstone boots on social media. He and Prueitt divorced in 2020.

Given the PE industry’s typical M.O. (i.e. the decade-long pyramiding of real estate and overleveraging on ever lower interest rates), I wouldn’t be surprised if Tartine is sinking deeper and deeper into debt – or might eventually end up like Dean & DeLuca.

In February 2020, a few short weeks before the Covid lockdown, 141 of Tartine’s >200 San Francisco Bay Area employees signed a letter, announcing their decision to unionize with the International Longshore and Warehouse Union. It came as a huge surprise, especially at a world-renowned bakery that boasts about ‚Äã"production at a human scale" and has been a training ground for young bakers from around the globe.

Tartine’s management declined to recognize the union, and hired Sam Singer, a longtime San Francisco crisis communications expert known for his work with controversial companies like Chevron’s Richmond oil refinery. After letting him go amid criticism, they then hired a Las Vegas-based firm called Quest Consulting to quash the unionizing effort. Quest’s founder, Lupe Cruz, has earned himself a reputation among labor organizers as “a notorious union-buster who specializes in influencing Latino-dominated workforces.”

In March 2021, over a year after voting and following a thorny, protracted dispute over 24 challenged ballots, the National Labor Relations Board announced that Tartine’s workers in San Francisco had officially unionized. In May 2022, the Tartine Union began negotiations for its first wage and healthcare contract, which stalled a few months later.

A single person at the right place comes up with a “unique” recipe at the right time can have the outsized effect of influencing a whole new generation of bakers, and even become a cult figure.

Nothing is more powerful than an idea whose time has come.

  • Victor Hugo

No single part of Tartine’s technique or bread is new or original to me. I’ve eaten there several times; nothing about it has blown my mind. Maybe it was groundbreaking a decade ago to the culinarily ignorant masses who grew up on industrial wheatish pulp?

That one guy who lives in San Francisco at the right time with the right trade shouldn’t get all the credit for this bread renaissance – East Coast journalists began to protest. People (mostly women) have been baking bread at home for thousands of years before Robertson and Prueitt opened Tartine.

Apparently, “nerds” over-engineering breadbaking, turning this homegrown, down-to-earth craft into something more technical and complicated than it should be, and “pushing” women out in the process is a huge problem. The gendering of baking has become a hot topic.

…one of my favorite things about JavaScript is when we discover things 20 years after other languages, besides like the concept of baking your own bread at home instead of purchasing it from the store, we act like we invented fat arrow functions, classes, immutable data, restructuring statements, functional programming – like, it’s like truly wild to witness.

…this baking bread thing seems to have come out of like nowhere and it’s interesting to see. … I was going to make fun of the parallels between baking bread – like baking bread from a recipe and implementing an algorithm of code, but I think that the real interesting and problematic parallel is the rhetoric with which JavaScript developers talk about bread. It’s super elitist and it’s mostly dudes.

why are there no women in tech baking bread? And I feel like – this is in all seriousness, I feel this pressure now to stop this in its tracks. … I’m worried about fucking bread. Like, you think I’d have enough emotional labor as a woman in tech to have to deal with baking bread – I don’t know.

  • Jenn Schiffer, Deconstruct Conf 2017

People in and around San Francisco making sourdough is such a surprising and novel phenomenon that it needs to be picked apart – because (gasp!) they happen to be men who work in tech and ruin whatever they lay their hands on for the sake of fashion and “disruption.”

Perhaps the pseudo-celebrity status of Chad Robertson, the ubiquity of Instagram shots that emphasize only the visual aesthetic of breads, etc. speak to humans' shallowness and egotism more than anything else.

Who cares about some JavaScript developer in San Francisco who bakes bread at home and runs a blog about it? If anything, it’s those who follow them keenly on social media that affirm their authority and turn them into some bread gods. Why are you so desperate for external validation?

A lot of people think that to be a real developer/baker, you need to be prolific on social media. If you don’t argue about your trade on Twitter, GitHub or Instagram, you don’t feel like you are a real developer/baker. Yeah sure. Only if you choose to play this game and be stuck in this rat race.

I don’t think the scientific approach to bread is a futile endeavor. Why can’t the scientific and the intuitive approaches co-exist?

The foundation of bread is super simple and those basic principles are still unchanged. I disagree that it’s total hubris to be attempting to innovate and move the art forward. Some folks are actually making significant innovations in breadmaking, and innovation is not an “American sickness” that needs to be cured. (In fact, I would argue that America needs more innovation – especially in manufacturing and engineering – that will tangibly improve the standard of living.) Breads produced with some of the new artisan methods today are actually really good – in ways that their predecessors simply were not. Just because something has been around for thousands of years doesn’t mean there aren’t many new discoveries to be had. Hell, it wasn’t until a couple of decades ago that people picked up on the fact that you don’t have to knead the dough to make great bread. Sometimes little things like this go undiscovered because no one bothered to look.

Only very recently in history has certain technology become available to us that has allowed us to exert super precise control over the baking environment (e.g. ambient temperatures, steam, etc.) and ingredients (e.g. varieties of grain, grinds, flour blends, strains of yeast). Bread keeps getting better and better because some bakers continue to tinker endlessly with these variables. New scientific analysis could herald a “golden age of fermentation.” Sure, not everyone cares about these things. For most people, bread is bread.

As a baker, you should remove ego from your mise en place, rethink your take on baking, and do some researching and discovering for new techniques and skills. There’s always room for improvement. And maybe, just maybe, you could find some new excitement, or get your mind blown, and impart that joy and passion through your baking. Every person that eats your bakes deserves that.

I haven’t been baking my whole life. My mom never baked bread, and I didn’t eat much bread growing up. I actually loathed baking for most of my life – kneading or using a dough mixer (another thing you have to wash) is absolutely tedious, and handling raw ingredients like eggs is totally disgusting. I didn’t have my first taste of artisan sourdough bread until 2014. In fact, I didn’t discover breadmaking until ~2019, well after the “tech bros” had invaded the sourdough trend and maybe even moved on, and after The New Yorker declared a comeback for bread and greeted it as the giddy limit of fake trendspotting.

I was initially drawn to breadmaking because of the science behind it – the microbiology and cellular gastronomy – more than the intuitive part. To me, sourdough brought bread back from the dead. Now I’m more enthused about transforming different grains into good bread. It’s not about making disruptive breads, but making breads that I really like.

“Tech bros invading sourdough” is not some panic-inducing mass-epidemic of nerds suddenly swarming every supermarket by the thousands for artisan flours and baking tools. ~4 years in, I’m still the only person I know who makes bread on a regular basis. Many types of people all over the world are getting more interested in breadmaking and trying it out, but it’s still pretty rare for someone to commit to it at the same level as myself.

As a side note, I think the fact that producing some common food item at home is now seen as “novel” speaks volumes about how removed we postmodern humans are from our food. Tovala and DoorDash are good examples.

My second experiment with Joaquin Oro (shared by friends at the California Wheat Commission) pushes the limits of dough hydration. Gorging the Joaquin Oro grown in water-scarce California with an absurd amount of water is quite the California conundrum.

Total

ingredient baker’s % weight
Joaquin Oro, 100% extraction (Eck Farms, CA) 100% 530g
H‚ÇÇO 134% 710g
whole wheat poolish 52% 275g
whole wheat levain 15% 80g
azuki bean pur√©e 7.1% 37.5g
sea salt (Gustus Vitae, CA) 1.4% 7.5g
olive oil (Awake - Brightland, CA) 5.7% 30g
tallow (home-rendered), softened 7.1% 37.5g

I used two leavens at different hydration levels in this dough.

Yeast water poolish

I pre-fermented ~24% of total flour in an overnight poolish, with homemade pineapple yeast water.

ingredient baker’s % weight
Joaquin Oro, 100% extraction (Eck Farms, CA) 100% 125g
pineapple yeast water (homemade) 120% 150g

You could substitute the yeast water with 1%-2% dry yeast + 120% plain H‚ÇÇO.

I let the poolish ferment for 12 hours at ~70¬∞F. When ripe, the poolish should be brimming with bubbles and double in volume.

Poolish modifies gluten, weakening it somewhat, so the dough stretches better as it ferments. For a strong-flour dough, a poolish will help bread rise taller.

Levain

ingredient baker’s % weight
Joaquin Oro, 100% extraction (Eck Farms, CA) 100% 40g
H‚ÇÇO 50% 20g
sourdough starter 50% 20g

I let the levain ripen at ~75¬∞F for 1 hour, and then retarded it in the fridge overnight.

When ripe, my levain smelt and tasted like a tart yogurt – or perhaps more like cr√®me fra√Æche that made me salivate and excited to eat more.

Final dough

ingredient baker’s % weight
Joaquin Oro, 100% extraction (Eck Farms, CA) 100% 365g
H‚ÇÇO, divided 148% 540g
whole wheat poolish 75% 275g
whole wheat levain 22% 80g
azuki bean pur√©e 10% 37.5g
sea salt (Gustus Vitae, CA) 2% 7g
olive oil (Awake - Brightland, CA) 8% 30g
tallow (home-rendered), softened 10% 37.5g

The process is built upon my previous wholegrain pan de cristal loaves:

  1. Autolyse the flour at 80% hydration for 2 hours in the fridge.
  2. Add the poolish, levain, and azuki bean pur√©e. Mix until well incorporated.
  3. Double hydration: Slowly drizzle in 2/3 of the remaining water, and Rubaud-mix until thoroughly absorbed. This requires a bit of patience, so take your time. Cover the dough and let it rest for 20 minutes at room temperature.
  4. Add the salt, and mix well.
  5. Triple hydration: Slowly add the rest of the water, while Rubaud-mixing until completely combined. Let the dough rest for another 20 minutes at room temperature.
  6. Gently mix in the olive oil and softened tallow. Let the dough rest and relax for 30 minutes.
  7. Bulk ferment the dough at ~70¬∞F for 4 hours, performing a coil-fold every 30 minutes during the first 2.5 hours. Folding a super-high-hydration dough like this kinda feels like handling water.
  8. Transfer the dough into a fridge and retard for 12 hours.
  9. Take the dough out of the fridge; divide it into two or leave it whole as a large loaf. Let it rest at room temperature for 2-3 hours (no shaping necessary).
  10. Bake as usual: 25-30 minutes at 350¬∞F.

I divided the dough into two approximately equal portions, baked one in the toaster oven, and kept the other one in the fridge for another 8 hours.

Bake #1

The 1st piece turned out great – exactly what I had expected from a hard red spring wheat.

The tallow has imparted some savory aroma to the bread.

The crumb is delightfully light and airy, almost like gossamer; it’s exceptionally soft and chewy.

The crust is so thin and crisp that it’s almost non-existent.

Sure, it doesn’t have Tartine bread’s shell of blistered mahogany, but the interior is so chewy and preternaturally moist that it shimmers in the light.

The delicate, nutty flavor of whole wheat Joaquin Oro shines through – perceptibly different from Turkey Red to me.

I like this pan de San Joaqu√≠n toasted; topped with salsa roja, crunchy lettuce and thinly-sliced Vadalia onions (for a pleasing texture contrast), and crumbled queso fresco.

Bake #2

Instead of baking the 20-hour retarded piece in an oven, I brought it to a Mardi Gras BBQ thingy and cooked it in a cast-iron skillet on a charcoal-fired grill. Who says February is a month to simply be endured – a penance to pay before late winter yields to spring?

Magic happens when meat meets charcoal smoke. What about breads?

I tossed a handful of black walnut and pistachio shells into the grill towards the end. Nut shells release a great smokey aroma when they burn, due to the oils that naturally occur in the shells. They burn pretty easily and add a marvelous boost of smoky sweetness to food.

This grilled pan de San Joaqu√≠n delivers an exciting punch of smoky char in first bite.

The crumb is wonderfully airy and springy like the first one, and the subtle tang of the bread becomes more pronounced with each successive bite, finishing on a question mark instead of an exclamation point.

Custardy and glistening.

I like this smoky pan de San Joaqu√≠n fresh or toasted; perfect for dunking in garlicky cioppino.

TL;DR

  1. Joaquin Oro is an excellent bread wheat for sourdough baking.
  2. You don’t need a San Francisco sourdough starter to make excellent bread.

This is part 2 of my California Grain Adventure. If you enjoyed it, why not check out my other breadstories or spread the word?

item.title: Shinsekai no Ambrosia
item.description: The OG fruit & nut energy bar.
item.content:
Noma, the Copenhagen restaurant that helped define a genre of ultra high-end, locally foraged, and culinarily groundbreaking cuisine, is closing in 2024. Over the last decade, being able to experience Noma has apparently become a status symbol. Funny how the culinary icon was forced to shut down after it found itself facing financial difficulties.

In October 2021, Noma – arguably the most prestigious kitchen in the world – started paying its interns (known as stagiaires) for the first time. And that has added $50,000 to the restaurant’s monthly operating expenses, according to the NYT.

Rene Redzepi, chef-owner of Noma, said Monday that it wasn’t possible to make the math of fine dining work for his almost 100 employees and himself. … In 2021, the restaurant lost money, even with government support, while selling $700 lunches.

  • Kate Krader, “Noma, One of the World‚Äôs Best Restaurants, Is Closing Its Doors”, Bloomberg

According to an annual report, Noma received üá©üá∞ kr10.9 million (USD ~$1.57m) in Covid-19 compensation from the Danish government in 2021 while booking a net loss of üá©üá∞ kr1.69 million (USD ~$240k); the previous year, it received üá©üá∞ kr8.05 million (USD ~$1.16m) in government financial aid and recorded a tiny profit of üá©üá∞ kr39,816 (USD ~$5,748).

Currently, one pays USD ~$500/person to eat a weeknight dinner soberly at Noma. The restaurant can seat ~42 diners comfortably. Let’s say 20 people dine at Noma every night Tues-Fri and 20 at Saturday lunch. $500 x 20 ppl x 5 days = $50,000/week in gross revenue (not even counting beverages), or >=$200k per month. If Noma is fully booked every day, it would make at least $105k/week, >=$440k a month, or >= $5m a year. And that’s just a baseline projection. $50,000/month in labor cost for ~100 employees = $500/month for each worker!!! üò±üò®üò≥üò±üò± Can you survive on that anywhere in the developed world?

If “the world’s most influential restaurant” that brings in at least a quarter million USD in gross revenue each freakin' month can’t keep its doors open while paying its workers a meager wage of $500/month, then this industry at large has some major restructuring and soul-searching to do. Numbers don’t lie.

The Finnish chef Kim Mikkola, who worked at Noma for four years, said that fine dining, like diamonds, ballet and other elite pursuits, often has abuse built into it.

‚ÄúEverything luxetarian is built on somebody‚Äôs back; somebody has to pay,‚Äù he said.

I can’t bring myself to mourn Noma’s closure, because there is no part of me that feels something is being lost or taken away. And no, I’ve never dined at Noma, so I can’t tell you how life-changing a Noma meal was. I did read The Noma Guide to Fermentation a few years ago and tried making the rye bread miso (“ryeso”).

I’m glad Noma existed and Ren√© Redzepi realized a business that exploits unpaid labor is unsustainable, financially and morally. I hope the next restaurant that rises to influence global cuisine as much as Noma did will be a pioneer in some sort of real sustainability, not just propelled by fanaticism around a singular genius or its avant-garde fascism.

The truth is, however elaborately prepared or miraculously transformed, at the end of the day it’s just food – something that you swallow and inevitably becomes shit. Maybe that’s what made Anthony Bourdain so depressed.

A human being is primarily a bag for putting food into.

  • George Orwell

A lot of things are upside-down in the brave new Po-Lo (post-lockdown) world. Expensive fine dining as we know it seems to be on its way out. In fact, another destination for fine dining (in Silicon Valley), Manresa, closed in late 2022.

I am reminded of The Menu. The movie takes place mostly inside Hawthorne, a fictional uber-luxurious restaurant on a small island that seats only a dozen customers a night at $1,250/person. Workers are stuck between the belief that what they are doing (i.e. passionately pursuing their dreams) is worth sacrificing everything for and the reality that they have surrendered their lives to grueling service work which the monied class treats as merely social status accessories.

There is something strange about real life – you can feel so plugged in and so distant at the same time. You want to be part of the action, but you find yourself on the outside. And then, if you get close enough, you realize that the main goal of so many on the inside is to keep you out, and to make you think they know something that you do not, which is patently untrue.

Towards the end of The Menu, Chef Slowik pours his heart and soul into making Margot a good old-fashioned cheeseburger, because he sees it as an opportunity to redeem himself from his failure to stay true to his art and make up for all the passionless meals he prepared for the rich. When Margot takes a bite and appreciates the burger for what it is – a filling meal that satiates her hunger – the chef finally feels proud and content.

This burger reminds me of lablabi, a working-class staple in Tunisia. To make lablabi, you basically pour a thin soup with boiled chickpeas over a pile of stale bread that’s torn up into tiny pieces. Lablabi is cheap, quick, and filling; it fuels you for the rest of the day and keeps you warm during the winter.

At the other end of the dining spectrum is “trailer trash food”, stuff that I imagine the main character in Barbara Kingsolver’s Demon Copperhead grew up eating. I haven’t forgotten the shock I experienced when I first encountered the ambrosia at a working-class eatery in South Carolina: canned fruits were mixed with canned whipped cream, mayonnaise, sugar, and mini marshmallows, and topped with Cool Whip. It’s apparently a Southern holiday tradition. (The OG ambrosia made in the 1800s used only 3 ingredients: orange slices, grated coconut, and sugar.)

A friend of mine recently went to Italy on vacation and brought me a panforte di Siena – a traditional Italian confection that’s a cross between fruitcake, candy, and Lebkuchen. Basically, a dense, sweet “cake” made from candied fruits, nuts, spices, a touch of flour, and a sugar/honey syrup, dusted in powdered sugar on all sides. It tastes absolutely delicious, but far too sweet for me. I wanted to make a less sweet version with pretty much the same ingredients.

I stumbled across hutzelbrot, looked into it further, and fell down a rabbit hole… Eric Carle’s hungry caterpillar ate das Fr√ºchtebrot??

Hutzelbrot is a German fruit bread, originally made with dried pears (called “hutzeln” in Alemannisch), but it gained many regional names as well – “zelten” (Bolzano), “schnitzbrot” (Schwaben), “birnebrot” (Das Allg√§u), “kletzenbrot” (Bavaria-Austria) or simply the more generic “fr√ºchtebrot” as it can be filled any dried fruits other than pears.

In the old days, the stingy farmers' wives would dry the leftover pears to avoid food waste and make the hutzelbrot on St. Thomas' day, December 21st (the winter solstice). The wives and maids would embrace their pear trees, with their hands and arms still covered in dough, to ensure a good harvest in the following year.

Nothing beats ye olde traditional recipe. From Wikipedia:

Originally Fr√ºchtebrot was made without honey, brown sugar or white sugar, with the sweetness coming only from the dried pears. Equally uncommon is Fr√ºchtebrot made of wheat dough. Using wheat dough makes the bread look less rustic, but also hinders the combustion of the fruits baked into it.

So, it’s the medieval OG energy bar – just dried fruits, nuts and a touch of rye flour!!!

An 18th-century manuscript describes celteno, a predecessor of Zelten. The recipe reads: “Take some Candia grapes, raisins, pine nuts, peeled almonds cut long, minutely cut lemon peel, aniseed seeds, candied citron, cinnamon powder, a little sugar, and a little flour and mix everything together. Take a small piece of brewer’s yeast, the size of a walnut…”

  • Sabina Montevergine, “Zelten”, La Cucina Italiana

The internet shows me many kinds of das Fr√ºchtebrot, which roughly fall into two categories:

  • yeast-leavened breads, such as this fr√ºchtebrot, Kletzenbrot aus der l√§ndlichen K√ºche, Schnitzbrot, and grandma’s original Fr√ºchtebrot (with rye flour). The yeasted dough usually goes through a first rise, before mixing with rehydrated dried fruits and nuts. The dough can barely enrobe the huge amount of add-ins, and acts more like a binder.
  • quick breads with baking powder, such as saftiges Fr√ºchtebrot and Apfelbrot.

Marcel Paa’s Fr√ºchtebrot-Powerbrot uses a yeasted wholegrain preferment and a sourdough levain, similar to Peter Reinhardt’s.

Taking a page from all of the above, I started my heretical experiment a few days ago.

Saccharified scald

ingredient baker’s %
coarse rye flour (svedjerug - Vestre Aschim, Norway) 100%
hot water 230%
white rye malt (diastatic) 1%
red rye malt (not diastatic) 1%

Mix everything together into a gravy. Cover and keep warm (~150¬∞F) for 3+ hours.

Thermophilic levain

Once the scald has saccharified and cooled off to ~120¬∞F, add a dollop of thermophilic starter (~7% of the total scald weight) – or plain yogurt with live and active cultures.

Mix them together and put a plastic cling wrap on the surface to remove as much air as possible. Leave it to sour anaerobically for 18 hours at 120-125¬∞F.

Pre-dough

After 18 hours, stir some stale bread crumbs (altus) into the thermophilic levain. My altus added up to 35% of the thermophilic levain’s weight.

Keep refrigerated until ready to use (you can also leave it overnight at room temperature).

Rye sour

ingredient baker’s %
whole rye flour (svedjerug - Vestre Aschim, Norway) 100%
rye sourdough starter 30%
h‚ÇÇo 80%

Mix all of the ingredients. Let it double at room temperature (which can take 8-12 hours depending on the temperature).

When fully ripened, cover tightly and refrigerate overnight, if necessary, to coordinate timing with the other parts. As you can see, I’m in absolutely no rush when I’m baking.

Final dough

ingredient baker’s %
whole rye flour (svedjerug - Vestre Aschim, Norway) 100%
pre-dough 1270%
rye sour 400%
dried fruits 800%
fresh grated coconut 200%
walnuts, toasted and chopped 200%
gingerbread spice (homemade) 20%
Havns√∏ flake salt 2%

Dried fruits included dates, figs, goji berries, raisins, prunes, pineapples, and mangoes. (I would add dried pears, apples, apricots, cranberries, cherries, etc. if I had them on hand.) I didn’t soak them, just chopped and mixed them directly into the final dough.

Combine everything in a large bowl. Mix for a few minutes until all the ingredients are evenly integrated and distributed into the dough.

Let the dough rest at room temperature for ~1 hour.

Transfer to a wet surface and shape.

Final proof: I let the dough rise for ~12 hours at 60¬∞F, until it had risen by ~50%.

Bake at 350¬∞F for 50 mins.

Cool on a rack and wait 24+ hours before slicing.

This bread turned out superbly moist and dense, like a liquidy L√§rabar. I couldn’t believe the knife came out clean! The scald worked out marvelously as a binder.

First bite reminded me of a cocoa banana bread, which is weird because there was absolutely no banana or cocoa in it.

It’s definitely not as decadent as il panforte di Siena, but plenty sweet enough for me (I could eat 2 small slices at most in one sitting). I would definitely put a lot more nuts into it next time, and maybe reduce the amount of fruits.

This ambrosial fruit bread should be relished in the depth of winter – it will help you discover that there is an invincible summer in you. „Ç®„ÇØ„Çπ„Çø„Ç∑„Éº„Å∏„ÅÆ„Éë„Çπ„Éù„Éº„Éà„Åß„Åô„ÄÇ

Stanley Ginsberg has a recipe for zelten in The Rye Baker. No mention that it’s just hutzelbrot by a different name.

Today is MLK Day in the US – a federal holiday. I was looking for grains on some Swedish net butiker this morning, and popped into a farm store statically built with Hugo (like this site you are reading right now). That’s a first and a breath of fresh air, given the virtually unassailable dominance by Shopify and Squarespace in e-commerce. It made me feel hopeful.

I’ve been thinking a lot about an anime I watched a long time ago – Shinsekai yori (Êñ∞‰∏ñÁïå„Çà„Çä / From the New World).

Eating another slice of my Shinsekai no Ambrosia (Êñ∞‰∏ñÁïå„ÅÆ„Ç¢„É≥„Éñ„É≠„Ç∑„Ç¢, “ambrosia of the new world”), before the world starts back up on Tuesday.

item.title: Arctic Maplemoon
item.description: An oaty raisiny whole wheat bread, made with Qu√©b√©cois ingredients.
item.content:
Just came back from a Christmas vacation in Qu√©bec, with a boatload of good memories and bagfuls of grains. Took the Old Canada Road Scenic Byway from Maine to Qu√©bec City, and felt like I had teleported across the Atlantic Ocean to Europe.

Qu√©bec sits just below the Arctic, which means it’s literally frozen half of the year. Holy shit, winter in Qu√©bec is cold – temperatures could easily drop to -35¬∞C (-31¬∞F) with the windchill. I had to get a parka. But I love how Canadians like to one-up each other over how cold their town is, as if winter was an acquired taste.

But Qu√©bec – especially la Ville de Qu√©bec – at Christmastime is a true winter wonderland, full of joie de vivre. It’s like Qu√©b√©cois have perfected the art of winter aversion therapy.

Qu√©bec is quite different from the rest of Canada (sort of like Scotland vs. England, or Puerto Rico vs. the US mainland). It’s a wonder that they have stayed together for this long. Qu√©bec gets a bunch of benefits (e.g. tax revenue, currency, and a governmental framework) from Canada that its own constantly-impoverished legislature could never provide, and Canada gets to enjoy a slice of Europe in between Ontario and New Brunswick. Friends with benefits.

Au Qu√©bec, on parle fran√ßais. But my French is rusty. Qu√©bec’s language issues are too deep, and some places absolutely refuse to speak a word of English. I wanted to have a good time and experience Qu√©bec City like a local, so I brushed up on my fran√ßais before arriving.

Holy poutine, Montmorency Falls is actually taller than Niagara Falls and absolutely stunning – even in the winter. The ice toboggan at Le Ch√¢teau Frontenac was incredibly thrilling and fun.

The two cornerstones of the Qu√©b√©cois cuisine are bread and meat (particularly pork), both of which I’m fond of. So I had the good fortune of sampling many local gourmet foods made by les artisans charcutiers and les boulangers des grains nobles. If you’ve never had saucissons (“French salami”) from La Ferme des Quatre-Temps and Charcuterie Charlevoisienne, or cheeses from Fromagerie des Grondines and Laiterie Charlevoix, then you haven’t lived!

I found an interesting indie magazine on Qu√©b√©cois food culture, Caribou. Oh, there’s also a 5-volume tome about the history of family cooking in Qu√©bec, Histoire de la cuisine familiale du Qu√©bec.

Given that Qu√©bec produces an overwhelming majority of the world’s maple syrup (sirop d’√©rable), it’s not surprising Qu√©b√©cois drizzle maple syrup on everything, even the eggs.

Anyway, I brought back some La Meunerie Milanaise wheat berries. No clue what specific cultivar these wheat berries are, other than some kind of hard red wheat grown in Qu√©bec. The nutrition label says it has 11.11% protein.

According to the Spring 2018 issue of Bread Lines, published by the Bread Baker’s Guild of America, La Milanaise whole wheat flour is a blend of hard red winter/spring wheats. The nutrition label says it has 11.67% protein. I doubt La Milanaise uses vastly different blends in its wheat berries and WW flours.

The way the grain industry works in Canada reminds me a lot of America’s three-tier system of alcohol distribution: producers sell only to processors, who then sell only through their distributors1, and distributors sell only to businesses. You rarely know which specific farm the grains come from, let alone meeting the farmers. You can’t buy La Milanaise products directly from La Milanaise anymore. You gotta find them at local retailers or place special orders through Avril Supermarch√© Sant√©.

I confess I hesitated about buying these wheat berries because I didn’t know what cultivars they were or who grew them, which is against my philosophy, but I decided to fuck it because YOLO…and it’s Canada where the face of flour is Robin Hood, owned by US multinational Cargill.

I also got some La Milanaise oat groats. Qu√©bec doesn’t exactly grow a lot of oats. There are >=30 organic oat producers in eastern Qu√©bec, mostly in Saguenay-Lac-Saint-Jean and Bas-Saint-Laurent, but altogether they produce just ~5% of Canada’s oats. The Prairies (especially Saskatchewan) produces 93%.

Obviously, Canada is great at growing oats, but not so great at processing them. Most of them are exported as raw commodities. Oat Canada gets its crops from Alberta, but only after the oats have been shipped to a facility in the US or Europe and processed into a concentrated protein powder. That’s the Canadian way.

Something else I learned about Qu√©b√©cois grains: a few decades ago, nobody believed that quality bread wheat could be grown in Qu√©bec. The hot, dry summers of Western Canada produced hard spring wheat, which yielded the ideal flour for bread.

Just before the turn of the millennium, the move towards artisan bread was starting to take hold in Qu√©bec. Bakers from France arrived in droves, and had an excruciatingly hard time producing French breads locally with the strong flours (~14% protein) milled from hard spring wheat. A growing demand thus emerged for a type of wheat that didn’t interest the Western Canadian farmers.

La Milanaise, which started out as a mixed farming business in the 1970s in the village of Milan in the Estrie region, rose up to the challenge of filling that void. With strong government support, La Milanaise pioneered the organic grain industry in Qu√©bec and nurtured the province’s wheat culture. Qu√©bec now dominates organic farming growth in Canada, and produces winter wheat with far more complex aromas than spring wheat.

La Milanaise has become a leading processor of organic grains in Canada, exporting grain products to the US, Europe and Latin America. It sources >=60% of its grain from Qu√©bec farmers, and only purchases out West what cannot be grown locally. (Obviously, agriculture is heavily subsidized and protected by le gouvernement du Qu√©bec.) It’s hard to tell which La Milanaise grains are grown in Qu√©bec and which are from elsewhere.

Additionally, La Milanaise has joined hands with Qu√©b√©cois bakery chain Premi√®re Moisson to found another mill, Les Moulins de Soulanges, to develop specialty flours tailor-made to the needs of Qu√©b√©cois artisan bakers. Flours from La Milanaise are featured in Daniel Leader’s Local Breads.

I’m not as keen on pre-milled flours as whole grains. But I did stop by Premi√®re Moisson (majority-owned by supermarket chain Metro since 2014) on Boulevard Lebourgneuf and got a WW buckwheat bread with Charlevoix hemp seeds. It was delicious and I felt fuckin' Canadian.

So I made a bread with La Milanaise grains:

ingredient baker’s %
whole wheat flour 85%
whole oat flour 15%
whole wheat levain 45%
water2 95%
Grade A dark maple syrup (Escuminac) 10%
grey Gu√©rande salt 1%
raisins (NaturellementBio3) 10%

I did the usual 24-hour cold ferment.

The whole wheat flour milled from La Milanaise wheat berries is very soft, but not as rouge as Turkey Red.

The bread is very aromatic during and after baking. The crust smells like caramel, chocolate and roasted nuts. The crumb is light, open and soft.

It tastes sweet and creamy, with some toasty wheatiness.

Madame Beno√Æt, a 20th-century Qu√©b√©cois food writer, once said:

“A recipe is only a theme, which an intelligent cook can play each time with a variation.”

I wholeheartedly agree with her.

Wholegrain rich sweet Hawaiian rolls served, using slight variations of the above recipe.

2022/12/23 - Round out the year with “Three Pines”, a deliciously moreish crime drama set in a small Qu√©bec village.

  1. A few small millers in Canada sell directly to consumers. ↩︎

  2. Just plain h‚ÇÇo. I did not bring back any fancy “vortex structured water” from Qu√©bec. ↩︎

  3. Avril Supermarch√© Sant√©’s private brand. Avril recently invested in its private lines, including Rolland Naturellement (French and Spanish wines), NaturellementBio (canned & dried goods), and Naturellement Gourmet (specialty products like gelato, balsamic vinegar and maple syrup). ↩︎

item.title: Desert Dynamo
item.description: Desert Dynamo, an impossible bread made with 100% Sonora whole wheat flour.
item.content:
I went camping at Patagonia Lake State Park in Arizona last week, and picked up a few bags of White Sonora wheat berries (from Ramona American Indian Farms, AZ).

White Sonora is a soft white winter wheat (SWWW) that has been adapted to the southwestern US, specifically the semi-arid climates of the Sonoran Desert in California and Arizona. It’s a very old wheat, first brought to the American Southwest by Spanish missionaries in the 17th century. They made a stretchy dough that gradually evolved into the flour tortilla.

With low gluten-forming potential, Sonora is considered an ideal flour for pastries rather than breads. Well… Since I’m not a fan of cakes and desserts, what should I do with my Sonora?

Turns out you can make a tall and fluffy bread just fine, with 100% Sonora flour. I learned a lot from my previous experiment with Warthog.

The bread has a lovely flavor and texture, which are further enhanced by adding ~1% diastatic barley malt1 and a squeeze of orange juice2 to the dough. Diastatic malt increases the conversion of starches to sugar, boosting the Maillard reaction of the crust. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) in orange juice tightens the gluten network3 and gives the bread a better rise. As a result, the crumb is more chewy, and the crust more caramelized.

You may be wondering, why not work with a strong wheat, to begin with? Why would anyone want to learn how to work with weak wheat varieties?

First of all, you get to enjoy the distinctive flavors of these weaker wheats: nutty, herbal, earthy, sweet, spicy, etc. Why wouldn’t a baker/foodie want to try all this variety?

When you buy packaged bread flour, whole wheat flour, or generic hard wheat berries, you are usually buying a blend of strong wheats grown in god-knows-where and mixed to achieve consistent characteristics such as a protein content of 12%-15% and the ability to form a strong gluten network. In contrast, when you buy a specific variety of grain, you are getting an individual product with unique characteristics (which vary somewhat from harvest to harvest).

Secondly, I believe it’s important to preserve crop biodiversity and move away from large-scale industrial monocultures – planting only a few strains of a single crop means that a new pest or virus could virtually wipe out an entire plant species. It’s time we give power back to the farmers who understand the land and know how to manage different varieties and species of plants.
