Biodiversity is critical to a robust food system, a prerequisite for food and nutrition security. Do I even need to mention the obvious benefit of delicious flavors?

“There are may of us who cannot but feel dismal about the future of various cultures. Often it is hard not to agree that we are becoming culinary nitwits, dependent upon fast foods and mass kitchens and megavitamins for our basically rotten nourishment.” - M.F.K. Fisher

Thirdly, protein percentage is not indicative of the wheat’s baking performance – the correlation between protein levels and gluten strength isn’t strong. It’s entirely possible to have high protein levels with weak gluten (e.g. durum, einkorn). Similarly, bread wheats grown in the more humid areas often have weaker gluten as well. This isn’t a bad thing – some people relish the softer crumb from weaker gluten.

It’s totally possible to make good bread with weak wheat, but it takes some adjustment. IMO, any baker who relies on high-gluten flour or added vital wheat gluten to produce good bread is a cheat. Being able to produce great breads from any type of wheat takes knowledge and skills.

So, how do you bake a bread with weak flour? The bassinage technique is a tip. Adding natural enhancers like diastatic malt and ascorbid acid, as mentioned earlier, is another. Here’s the door to the rabbit hole.

I ran the Sonora wheat berries through the mill several times to get the finest grind possible. Smaller particles help the gluten bond better.

I also bolted the flour to take out 10% of the coarsest bits, which I scalded and then fed to the levain. It was all added back in the final dough; the wholegrain integrity of the bread is never compromised.

Dough:

ingredient baker’s %
~90% extraction Sonora flour (Ramona Farms, AZ) 100%
bran levain 40%
water (65% in autolyse + 17% in bassinage) 82%
fresh orange juice4 10%
flaxseeds, freshly ground 5%
diastatic barley malt powder 1%
salt 1%

Add-ins:

ingredient baker’s %
fresh jalape√±os, diced 10%
Colby cheese + jalape√±o cheddar, grated (Arizona Farms) 8%
toasted millet 5%

Mix the flour with salt, malt and flaxseeds. Autolyze with cold orange juice and ~2/3 of the water for 20-30 minutes in the fridge. The gluten will develop more readily in a drier dough environment.

Add the levain and the remaining water (eau de bassinage) gradually, and mix until thoroughly incorporated. Minimal handling is preferred.

Transfer the dough to a fridge right away and ferment for 24 hours. Do a coil-fold every 3-4 hours. Sprinkle the add-ins during the last couple of folds.

After 24 hours of bulk fermentation, I shaped the dough into a log, put it in a sandwich loaf pan, and let it rise at room temperature for ~3 hours before baking.

The bread is light and creamy, spicy and sweet.

  1. Simply put, diastatic malt is a grain which has been sprouted, dried and grounded into a powder. It contains active enzymes (diastase) that degrade starch to maltose, a simple sugar that yeasts love. You can easily make diastatic malt at home, with high-quality whole grains. ↩︎

  2. According to several studies, orange has the highest vitamin C content of all citrus fruits. ↩︎

  3. Bread Chemistry explains: “Ascorbic acid is, of course, a reducing agent but, during dough mixing, the enzyme ascorbic acid oxidase, naturally present in flour, catalyses its conversion to its oxidising form, dehydroascorbic acid (DHAA). In a reaction catalysed by another flour enzyme, DHAA converts glutathione (GSH), a tripeptide naturally found in wheat flour, to its dimer (GSSG). GSH, but not GSSG, can form disulfide bonds ‚Äì so removing GSH prevents it from disrupting the disulfide crosslinking that otherwise form between gluten proteins.” ↩︎

  4. Fresh orange juice contains a lot more biologically active ascorbic acid than pasteurized orange juice. ↩︎

item.title: Aquaboogie van Wheatsworth
item.description: A series of heretically high-hydration wholegrain pan de cristal experiments.
item.content:
I have been experimenting with wholegrain pan de cristal. Impossible? “Water makes the baker rich.”

100% Turkey Red

ingredient baker’s %
whole wheat flour (Turkey Red - Stephens Land & Cattle, KS) 100%
cold aqua (autolyse 75% + bassinage 45% + salt 10%) 130%
whole wheat levain 40%
salt 1%
olive oil (Peranzana) 20%

The process is pretty much the same as in the 80% extraction version – except that I gorged with dough a lot more water during bassinage and olive oil after.

A very light and airy crumb. Reminded me of my first Turkey Red bread, but this one is much more chewy and “spongy.”

70% Turkey Red + 30% triticale

Triticale (Tricosecate) is a man-made cross of wheat (Triticum) and rye (Secale), exhibiting characteristics of both grains, i.e. triticale contains the complex flavor and nuance of rye, mellowed by the easier behavior of wheat. It has been around for well over a century. It was first bred in labs in the late 1800s in Scotland and Germany, in order to combine the yield potential and grain quality of wheat with the disease and environmental tolerance of rye.

In Star Trek episode “The Trouble with Tribbles”, the protection of a grain developed from triticale is the central focus. This grain was a genetically-engineered hybrid of wheat and rye with four distinct lobes per kernel, hence the name “quadro-triticale.” Mr. Spock attributes the ancestry of the root grain, triticale, to 20th-century Canada.

Indeed, in 1953 the University of Manitoba in western Canada began the first intensive triticale breeding program in North America, working mostly with durum wheat-rye crosses. Early efforts concentrated on developing a high-yield, drought-tolerant human food crop species suitable for marginal wheat-producing areas.

It was only after the 1970s that farmers started to grow this grain on a commercial scale – mostly for forage or fodder. Over the years, triticale’s popularity has surged and ebbed. Farmers tend to either love the crop and continually plant it, or give it a go once and decide they like other grains better. Triticale has recently resurfaced as a choice grain for high-protein feed.

In the vast potpourri of hybrid grains that have been developed so far, at least this one has been around for well over a century and has had more research than some other stuff that has been engineered in the last ~5 years.

Triticale is mostly grown in Europe (Poland, Germany, Belarus, France and Russia), but you can find it easily in North America and Australia these days.

In an attempt to better understand the idiosyncrasies of this grain, I ferreted out as much information as possible on the internet. What I’ve learned:

  1. Triticale actually has a higher protein content than wheat and, at the same time, a lower gluten content than wheat due to genetic inheritance from rye. The latter trait has deprived the grain of superstardom in the breadmaking fraternity. A suggested solution: blend <=30% triticale flour into a wheat dough.
  2. Unlike rye, triticale actually has a very poor ability to absorb water. Start with low hydration (~60%) if making a 100% triticale bread, and don’t expect a tall, fluffy loaf.
  3. Triticale appears to benefit from the LAB fermentation process of a natural leaven. This helps to make the protein more soluble and improves the viscosity of the dough itself.
  4. A triticale dough also benefits from minimal handling, i.e. “no knead” and “folding”, because it has a low mixing tolerance.

Triticale seems to be a good candidate for blending, rather than using it totally on its own.

ingredient baker’s %
whole wheat flour (Turkey Red - Stephens Land & Cattle, KS) 70%
whole triticale flour (Sunflower Acres, CO) 30%
cold aqua (autolyse 75% + bassinage 45% + salt 5%) 125%
whole triticale levain 40%
salt 1%
olive oil (Peranzana) 20%

The 70% wheat 30% triticale flour blend yielded a spongy bread with honeycomb crumb.

Compared to the 100% Turkey Red pan de cristal, this 30% triticale version has a milder flavor and a less open but more moist crumb. Tasty in a different way.

50% Turkey Red + 50% spelt

ingredient baker’s %
whole wheat flour (Turkey Red - Stephens Land & Cattle, KS) 50%
whole spelt flour (Oberk√ºlmer - Tom & Mary Klein, OH) 50%
cold aqua (autolyse 75% + bassinage 45% + salt 10%) 130%
caramelized onion pur√©e 10%
whole spelt levain 40%
salt 1%
olive oil (from garlic confit) 20%
fermented jalape√±os 15%
wild garlic leaves 5%
shredded cheese 20%

The jalape√±os and garlic went in the dough during coil-folds.

I piled heaps and heaps of cheeses (from Hemme Brothers Creamery, MO) on top of the dough, just before it went into the oven:

  • aged cheddar
  • applewood smoked cheddar
  • sour cream & onion cheddar curds
  • garlic dill cheddar curds

Indulgent like those cheese slippers at Fervere Bakery in Kansas City.

The golden crispy cheese-laden crust is the crown jewel.

The crumb is juicy, bold and spicy.

After these experiments, I doubt I will miss making lower-hydration wheat breads again. If I’ve learned anything about my baking, it’s this: why “do” when I can “overdo”? The pan de cristal is a game-changer.

Only those who will risk going too far can possibly find out how far one can go.

  • T.S. Eliot

item.title: Orange Sunshine
item.description: A seedelicious bread made with 100% Warthog whole wheat flour and a bucket of orange juice.
item.content:
The first time I ate homemade bread was in 2011 in Kansas City, when I was backpacking across the US. I had no idea that bread was something you could make at home. Prior to that, my experience with bread had been exclusively limited to the typical white mush served at school cafeterias. It was so disgustingly bland, empty, and unfulfilling – not to mention it was also emblematic of everything that was wrong with America – that I developed a sort of White Bread PTSD and swore I’d never eat another slice of bread after college.

Funny how the Covid lockdown has inspired/forced a lot of people to bake breads at home – and even sell their homemade breads on Etsy. It has forced me to pay more attention to where I source my food from and whether they will always be available.

A number of artisan-ish bakeries across the country are selling their bread flours nicely packaged in eco-friendly brown paper bags at “pandemic special” prices, to make up for their lost business & revenue due to the shutdown and retain customer relationships.

Last month, King Arthur Flour rebranded itself to King Arthur Baking Company. The flour company was founded in 1790, and is America’s first flour company. They have re-aligned the company to reflect their mission – “bake joy.” King Arthur is now a lifestyle company, like Lululemon, Peloton and Chipotle. I don’t buy King Arthur’s flours or care for its recipes, but I do find that rebranding – particularly the timing – interesting.

Literally every state has a “local” flagship producer. IL has Janie’s. NY has Farmer Ground Flour. OR has Camas Country Mill. NC has Carolina Ground. TX has Barton Springs Mill. AZ has Hayden Flour Mills. Who is MO’s local artisan flagship producer?

If I were going to bring coastal friends “Missouri-grown” non-touristy gifts, I wouldn’t know what to get – other than t-ravs, provel, and maybe some local booze. I know the MO Department of Agriculture has a program called Missouri Grown, but the local goodies gift box it has put together is a joke.

Missouri always feels like a giant black hole of locally grown grains. Sure, Missouri grows a ton of soybeans, corn and soft wheat. I mean, it’s a Corn Belt state. But most of them are exported via the Mississippi River, and the rest processed into animal feed, industrial inputs, and biofuels. Only a tiny percentage stays local. The US Soybean Export Council and American Soybean Association (which has a political action committee called SoyPAC) are both headquartered in St. Louis (STL). Monsanto was founded in STL and headquartered here for over 100 years, and its new parent, Bayer AG, still established its North American HQ here. The world’s biggest grain traders – Archer Daniel Midland (ADM), Bunge, and Cargill – all have major operations in STL as well. (These 3, along with Louis Dreyfus, control ~90% of global grain trade and have enormous power over grain prices.) Evidently, their presence here impacts local farmers and agri-food system.

Missouri certainly doesn’t have a shortage of local producers, and the flagship local product with (inter)national recognition doesn’t have to be bread wheat – South Carolina has done exceptionally well with heirloom rice renaissance, for example.

I had the good fortune of living a stone’s throw away from Anson Mills in Charleston for a number of years, and got to witness its metamorphosis to the Palmetto State’s flagship artisan producer/purveyor, an explosive commercial success with international fame. Tourists from all over the world flock to Charleston, SC to visit Anson Mills and experience the antebellum culinary past. It has become a culinary tourist destination in and of itself. More incredibly, the entrepreneurs behind Anson Mills are not even SC natives. What’s the MO equivalent of Anson Mills or Carolina Gold rice, or of even San Francisco’s Tartine? My point is, MO local producers have a branding/PR problem. Tom Cruise is a globally recognizable brand. Janie’s of Illinois is a national brand. What’s the most recognizable MO brand? The only local product brand (even remotely) familiar to people from out of state or overseas might be Hammons Black Walnuts, which does have a D2C web store, but its branding and packaging leave a lot to be desired.

Kansas City (the Wheat Belt’s buckle) seems rife for a “single-origin wheat” renaissance that will help rebuild local economy and reclaim the Wheat State’s agricultural heritage. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Kansas City had dozens of flour mills. Grain magnate Frank A. Theis (namesake of Theis Park) wrote in a 1938 article in The Kansas City Star, “No other industry, directly or indirectly, has been more closely identified with the growth of Kansas City.” In South Carolina and North Carolina, the cultivation of revival grains is a rapidly expanding enterprise.

I desperately wanted to find a Missouri-grown bread wheat. I went on a relentless hunt for this elusive prize, with little success. All neighboring states grow bread wheats, why not Missouri? My curiosity took me down a rabbit hole… What started out as a seemingly trivial question turned into a herculean quest and then Mission Impossible.

Obviously, most people buy flours, not grains. So flour was where I started.

A bearded guitarist and baker used to sell his sourdough breads at farmers' markets and some restaurants in STL. One of his breads was pan bigio, an Italian country loaf made with “local Cape Girardeau whole wheat flour.” I tried to find out which Cape Girardeau farm/mill that was (since I wasn’t aware there even was one), but he shut down his operations in March and went dark.

I called up the few artisan-ish bakeries in STL that pride themselves on using “locally grown and milled wheat” to ask what flours they use and where they source them from. Not only did they refuse to tell me anything, but also they got very confused and in some cases suspicious… as if I had broken an unspoken cultural taboo. One of the nicer bakers directed me to the proverbial purveyors of “unique local organic artisanal products,” aka. specialty retailers that label everything with 10+ haute adjectives and lists everything 1,000% higher than MSRP. Well, that was a very curious experience. I’m not sure whether these bakeries 1) genuinely use local ingredients as much as they claim, 2) severely lack business acumen to begin with, or 3) are simply too small-minded and uncreative.

I went back to the drawing board and started doing some research, when I found out that the band, from Delaware, Maryland, northern Virginia and southern Illinois and through Missouri to the eastern part of Kansas, is known for growing soft winter wheat. In fact, whatever wheat ends up flourishing on a commercially viable scale in Missouri is usually soft winter wheat and mostly exported, although Mizzou Cooperative Extension’s hard winter wheat trials in several locations around the state are successful. Most of the commercial bakeries here source their bread flours by truckloads from western Kansas.

After a few days of hopeless internet research, I was on the verge of giving up. Serendipitously, a couple of small farms in central/western MO came across my radar – they grow organic hard red winter wheat!

So this is how I found 180 Farms in Sweet Springs, MO. I called up Greg Guier earlier last week week, to inquire about his organic wheat berries. Holy shit, Greg is one of the nicest and most down-to-earth people I’ve ever talked to. Some Midwesterners are just frighteningly friendly! He told me this year’s Warthog Red, a hard red winter wheat, was still being harvested and would be ready in a few days, and last year’s Darby White, a hard white winter wheat, was readily available. He said he delivers only to Kansas City, because he tried for years to set up delivery arrangements in STL but couldn’t get anyone interested.

I was going camping in the Ozarks this weekend anyway, so I took a detour and stopped by Greg’s farm to scoop up some freshly harvested Warthog wheat berries. (Heck, even swung by the Overland Park Farmer’s Market and procured some heritage Meishan pork from Odd Bird Farm in Weston, MO.) Turns out, that was a great decision.

Warthog is a modern HRWW with a moderate protein content (10%-11%). I remember Warthog was hugely popular at the NYC Greenmarket a few years ago (thanks to GrowNYC Grains, a distributor/hub that promotes and sells local grains in the Northeast). Farmer-miller Thor Oechsner planted Warthog for the first time in 2010, loved it, and grew to become the largest Warthog producer in the Northeast. Then Janie’s Mill picked it up, too.

I did read about Warthog’s relatively low protein level for a HRWW, and kept that in mind while working with the flour. In fact, Oechsner recommended blending Warthog with a spring wheat flour to boost protein content while letting Warthog’s special flavor shine through.

Nah. I’m gonna go Warthog all the way through.

First step: mill the Warthog wheat berries several times to get the finest grind possible.

ingredient baker’s %
whole wheat flour (Warthog - 180 Farms, MO) 100%
rye levain 40%
water 42%
fresh orange juice 42%
diastatic barley malt powder 1%
flaxseeds, freshly ground 5%
salt 2%
soaker 33%
seed mix (for coating) 5%

The science behind incorporating orange juice and diastatic malt is explained in a later post. TL;DR: Diastatic malt increases the conversion of starches to sugar, boosting the caramelization of the crust. Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) in orange juice tightens the gluten network and gives the bread a better rise.

Soaker:

ingredient baker’s %
quinoa 25%
sunflower seeds 25%
whole flax seeds 25%
black sesame seeds 25%
orange juice 150%

You know my usual M.O.

The crumb doesn’t look too bad. Excuse my cutting.

Pretty darn tender and juicy.

Yum, the flavor is superb.

A great backpacking bread.

item.title: Breadford von Regrainton
item.description: A hearty re-grained bread, made with spent grains and Glenn whole wheat flour.
item.content:
I picked up a bag of Glenn wheat berries from Kenter Canyon Farms at the Atwater Village Farmers' Market in Los Angeles. It cost ~$2/lb, not cheap but not ridiculously overpriced either. The Glenn wheat was grown on Kenter Canyon Farms in Ventura County, along the south side of the Santa Clara River.

Glenn is a modern HRSW developed by a NDSU breeding program to provide better scab resistance and higher yield. It was released by the North Dakota Agricultural Experiment Station in the spring of 2005. It has a fairly high protein content of 13%-14%. I have seen quite a few local and regional mills across the country label Glenn as a “heritage” wheat – very curious.

I had long wanted to bake a treberbrot, a hearty German bread made with the addition of spent grains from brewing beers. The spent grain adds some sweetness, texture and a lot of fiber to the bread.

First, I milled the Glenn wheat berries, and sifted half into a 80% extraction flour, leaving the other half wholegrain (100% extraction).

Next, I built a levain with

  • sifted-out wheat bran; and
  • a smooth pur√©e of spent grains (from brewing Berliner Weiss) and boiled jackfruit seeds.

To make the dough stronger, I decided to use a 2-dough lamination method.

Dough #1:

ingredient baker’s %
80% extraction wheat flour (Glenn - Kenter Canyon Farms, CA) 100%
h2o 85%
bran levain 40%
salt 2%

This will be the stronger half of the dough that lifts the whole bread. You can totally swap water for beer here.

Dough #2:

ingredient baker’s %
whole wheat flour (Glenn - Kenter Canyon Farms, CA) 100%
h2o 70%
spent grain pur√©e 60%
bran levain 20%
salt 2%
toasted flaxseeds 5%

I mixed 1 part spent grains to 1 part water, and pur√©ed the mixture in a blender. Then I autolyzed the flour, along with the flaxseeds, in this thick grainy smoothie diluted with water.

With all of the wheat bran added back to the dough through the levain, this bread retains its whole-wheat integrity.

Add-ins:

ingredient baker’s %
spent grains 10%
sunflower seeds 5%
roasted papaya seeds, ground 5%
raisins 5%

Roasted papaya seeds have a dark cocoa brown color and smell deeply aromatic. They taste like peppercorns.

I did 4 folds with each dough during the first 3 hours. Then I combined both doughs by gently stretching them out into big rectangles and placing dough #2 on top of dough #1. I sprinkled the add-ins during lamination.

The dough was bulk-fermented for 5 hours in total at room temperature, shaped into a taut boule (dusted with grated coconut), and then retarded at 40¬∞F for 10 hours.

Next day, I let the dough warm up for a few hours until ~100% risen. I baked it on a shitty pizza pan in my ghetto toaster oven.

It grew so big during baking that it nearly filled up every cubic inch of the toaster oven!

The crust came out crispy and thin. The crumb is so freakin' airy.

The taste is deeply flavorful with a mild tang and a subtle sweetness from spent grains and raisins.

Superbly delightful.

NGL, it tasted even better the next day.

A later variation:

Can’t believe it’s already December. Where did the year go?

In review, 2019 has been my Year of Fermentation. I read Sandor Katz’s The Art of Fermentation and Ren√© Redzepi’s The Noma Guide to Fermentation. I got into sourdough breadmaking (and bread chemistry) seriously for the firs time. I experimented audaciously with literally anything I could get my hands on: vegetables, beans, grains, milk, fish… From lactic acid bacteria (LAB), I ventured into fungi – koji (Aspergillus oryzae) and tempeh (Rhizopus oligosporus). It’s been a very memorable year and an unbelievably fulfilling one.
